images.alt: Photo of ports on back of stereo receiver
images.figcaption: The back of my Yamaha R-S201 receiver showing a 75Ω coaxial female F-connector antenna jack

images.describedby: Generated map showing broadcast transmitter locations centered around the city of Brentwood in the San Francisco Bay Area.
images.figcaption: Generated map showing broadcast transmitter locations centered around the city of Brentwood in the San Francisco Bay Area.

images.alt: Photograph of two metal water pipes entering a wall. Attached to each pipe is a ground clamp. An unshielded heavy wire runs between the ground clamps.
images.figcaption: Two pipes bonded together with a solid core wire.

images.alt: Photograph of the outside of a house showing the main electrical box, the water main, and the natural gas meter.
images.figcaption: This house was built in 2001 and either does not have an actual ground rod or the ground rod is completely burried and is not accessible. However since the water main is within five feet of the main electrical box, the water main could be used as a ground rod. Paint would have to be scraped off before attaching the clamps for the earthing wires from an antenna.

images.alt: Photo of ports on back of stereo receiver
images.figcaption: The back of my Yamaha R-S201 receiver showing a 75Ω coaxial female F-connector antenna jack for FM and a two push-wire connectors for AM.

images.alt: Photograph of the inside of telecommunications box.
Photograph of the Comcast/Xfinity grounding block.

metadata.dc:title: Cutting The Cable
metadata.dc:description: A guide to switching to Over The Air digital broadcasts
metadata.dc:creator: Michael A. Peters
metadata.schema:accessibilitySummary: This publication attempts to conform to WCAG 2.0 Level AA. Validation by an accessibility expert has not yet been done.
